arm_group.arm_group_label: scar, Fat Graft, Visual Analogue Scale
arm_group.description: patients received autologous fat grafting in scar areas

brief_summary.textblock:
Traumatic wounds inflict small- and large-fiber sensory nerve damage, causing neuropathic
      pain in scar tissue. Autologous fat grafting has been clinically shown to improve scar
      quality, but scantly study has explored its effects on pain. The aim of the study was to
      survey its effect on pain.

clinical_study.brief_title: Autologous Fat Graft Alleviate Scar Pain

detailed_description.textblock:
Methods: From February 2008 and June 2013, a total of 36 patients received autologous fat
      grafting in scar areas. Patients who Douleur Neuropathique 4 Questions  (scores >4/10) were
      enrolled this study. The Visual Analogue Scale  (VAS), and Neuropathic Pain Symptom
      Inventory (NPSI) were used to evaluate pain preoperatively and postoperatively after 1 week,
      4 weeks, and 24 weeks. The mechanism of trauma, duration of allodynia, fat graft volume, and
      total follow-up time were recorded.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  February 2008 and June 2013, patients received autologous fat grafting in scar areas
             and also had pain over scar area before surgery

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  patients refused to participate the study

study_pop.textblock: patients received autologous fat grafting in scar areas

clinical_study.official_title: Alleviation of Neuropathic Scar Pain With Autologous Fat Graft
